OVERALL SITUATION
2. aid that his assessment was that the overall situation had deteriorated sharply since his last visit. The Taliban B6
were stronger, and more confident, than ever. ISAF was inflicting heavy losses on them, but the scale was as nothing
compared with what the mujahideen had endured at the hands of the Russians. Moreover, the change in rules of
engagement — to prevent civilian casualties, and fewer night raids — had been interpreted by the Taliban as signalling
weakness on NATO's part. In i e w , most of the East, and Kunduz, was effectively lost to the Taliban and their
fellow travellers. US forces in the East controlled the ground they occupied or passed over, but little more: they were in
a similar position to the Soviet Army. Moreover, the population did not want to back them, and was resisting US
attempts to set up tribal militias or implant US Special Forces in the villages. did, however, acknowledge that he
had heard that the US Marines in Helmand were behaving much more sensitively towards the population than had been
expected. But the situation in Marjah was not good. Of course, the Marines held the ground, but violence would
continue for months or years. This did not offer the positive signal of momentum for which the Coalition had been
hoping.

column1: to invite the wealthiest individuals and families in America to commit to giving the majority of their
wealth to the philanthropic causes and charitable organizations of their choice either during their
lifetime or after their death. Each person who chooses to pledge will make this statement publicly
along with a letter explaining their decision to pledge. At an annual event
column2: those who take the pledge

column1: will come together to share ideas and learn from each other.
The Pledge is a moral commitment to give
column2: not a legal contract. It does not involve pooling money

column1: or supporting a particular set of causes or organizations. While the Giving Pledge is specifically
focused on billionaires
column2: the idea takes its inspiration from efforts in the past and at present that

column1: encourage and recognize givers of all financial means and backgrounds. We are inspired by the
example set by millions of Americans who give generously (and often at great personal sacrifice) to
make the world a better place.
WHO: The Pledge currently has forty participants
column2: listed below in alphabetical order. To date

column1: are American

From: Verveer, Melanne S <VerveerMS©state.gov>
Sent: Wednesday, October 27, 2010 7:50 AM
To:
Subject: Thank you!
You were so terrific at the UN. The statements of gratitude are pouring in. I will take your message to Denmark. The
Nordics will be ecstatic.
Last night at Avon, I got many messages for you from people who want to be helpful, particularly from Anna Quinlan and
Patrick Dempsey. I'm hoping to get more $ from Avon to fund VAW grants. We are inundated with requests. Reese
Witherspoon will go to Russia next year for our women's summit. She's popular there so would be good. Nothing much
has happened vis a vis Russian women and US engagement since your efforts in the 90's so we are attempting to restart
are relationship with them .They been going backwards in terms of progress.
I'm attaching the email I sent Jake and Kurt on the NZ and Australian initiatives.
Have a good trip.
From: Campbell, Kurt M
To: Verveer, Melanne S; Sullivan, Jacob 3
Sent: Sat Oct 23 07:43:50 2010
Subject: Re: Asia trip
This is terrific Melanne and many thanks. Kurt
From: Verveer, Melanne S
To: Campbell, Kurt M; Sullivan, Jacob J
Sent: Fri Oct 22 21:41:33 2010
Subject: Asia trip
I just wanted to give you some background on the initiatives that New Zealand and Australia have put together to
empower women in the Pacific region and which they would like to spotlight during the Secretary's trip.
NZ wants to announce a collaboration between us and their government to increase women's political participation in
the Pacific region. Their development agency has made this a priority for the Secretary's trip. Our hope is that S will
welcome the collaboration in her remarks at a business leaders, et al reception.
Australia wants to announce a collaboration with us on an initiative to combat violence against women in the region. I
don't know where this will be included in S's remarks, but I hope it will. Both governments are committing significant
resources; we are committing much less, but Australia and NZ are eager to partner with us to address challenges in the
Pacific region.
I wanted to briefly share some thoughts on this formed during my last trip to China. It made the collaboration with NZ
and Australia on deeper engagement with the Pacific Islands on women and development issues that much more
compelling.
I was in Shanghai and Beijing last month to speak at the All-China Women's Federation (ACWF) international women's
forum to commemorate the 15th anniversary of the Beijing women conference and to follow up on our interest to launch
with the Chinese government the US-China Women Leaders Forum.
UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department of State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05775470 Date: 08/31/2015
UNCLASSIFIED U.S. Department of State Case No. F-2014-20439 Doc No. C05775470 Date: 08/31/2015
The ACWF is a mass organization affiliated with the Chinese Communist Party with strong leaders, huge resources and
powerful mobilizing forces throughout the country. The Chair, Chen Zhili, is also the Deputy Chair of the National
People's Congress, a former State Councilor; the President, Song Xiuyan, is a former governor of Qinghai Province and
rumored to be appointed as a State Councilor after the change of central leadership in 2012. I met with both of them
when I was there.
As I walked into the welcoming dinner in Shanghai, I found almost everyone I know of significance who works on
women's issues from Southeast Asia, the Pacific and Africa in attendance. However, I did not see government reps from
Europe or NEAsia. It appeared to me that the forum was targeted to engage countries and regions where China is
expanding its influence.
I know S is going to give a policy speech in Australia during this trip. I hope that you will include our commitment to
women in the Pacific Islands, especially through these proposed collaborations with Australia and NZ.
As you know very well, the 12 Pacific Islands, though small in size, represent 12 votes in the UN. They long for our
attention and collaboration. I think women's development issues are one ideal way to further our interests and
engagement.
Have a good trip!
Melanne

Dinner with Al Jazeera (AJ) staff: Al Director General Wadah Khanfar will host a dinner on May 1 with senior Al staff,
including AJ English Managing Director Tony Burman. We expect 7 people on the Al side and 6 on ours. (The dinner is
schedule for 8pm in a private room in the Four Seasons; post is making reservations for the party to stay in the same
hotel.)
